patterns: What do I do during immersion
How do I immerse
what should I focus on during immersion
what do I focus on during immersion
How to immerse
how to do active immersion
What do I do for immersion as an absolute beginner
what do i do in immersion
responses:
What exactly you do during immersion is hard to explain. The video linked below attempts to clairify this, but here is the answer in short. Do whatever you have to do to understand what you are consuming. This does not mean stop and look up every word you don't know to try and understand everything you are consuming. This is not advised to do often. This means to focus on the element preventing you from understanding your immersion.

In the beginning, this will be the sounds of the language. When you first start, you won't be able to hear the language properly. Most of it will sound like gibberish, so your focus should be on listening as intently as you can to listen to the sounds of the language. Once you start hearing the sounds better, you will begin to start picking out words. Some of the words you will recognize from your flashcards. Others will just be words you have heard in your immersion a lot and stick out. Words will eventually turn into sentences and into groups of sentences, scenes, and ultimately entire stories.

If you are still confused, try watching the video linked below and ask me some of the related questions. Good luck!

responses:
**__How long will this take? How much should I immerse?__**

The short answer is every day and as much as you can without negatively affecting more essential things in your life, like health, job, relationships, etc. The more detailed answer is.

This is a complicated answer because, in the end, we just don't know. Everyone learns at different rates. It also depends on the quality of your immersion, how well you are at keeping focus, your goals, and many more factors. Assuming you don't speak any other Asian languages, you can assume it will require a significant amount of immersion to reach a high level. That being said, here are some basic benchmarks. (These estimates are a guide only and differ from person to person significantly)

**3 Years to Speaking**
We advise getting at least 3+ hours of active immersion and another 3+ hours of semi-active/passive immersion a day to reach the output stage within 3 years. However, by Refold standards, at this point, your comprehension level will be so high that you will already be at a higher level in the language than most ever accomplish.

**Minimum amount**
We do recommend trying to get a minimum of 2 hours of active immersion a day. Anything 1 hour or less likely won't lead to satisfactory progress in a language like Japanese.

**There is no limit but be careful**
The more you immerse, the faster your progress will be. So if you have time, always opt to get more exposure to the language and hunt down ways to add more immersion time. But don't sacrifice physical or mental health, relationships, your job, and other more important things. Learning a language is excellent, but it won't make your life suddenly perfect. Once you speak the language, you want a life and people to enjoy it with.

That being said, make sure you have a healthy life outside of immersion. But with that being said, assuming the above is being protected, the more, the better.

responses: Immersion is simply consuming content in your target language (TL) created by natives for natives. Active immersion is immersion where you are entirely focused with the intent to understand it. Your attention isn't divided between other tasks, but rather you are fully dedicated to understanding the content you are consuming. So watching Anime, Movies, reading novels, light novels, watching YouTube videos, and more, are all examples of active immersion. In Refold, we break active immersion up into two types. **Intensive immersion** and **free flow** immersion. Learn more about active immersion and the two types of active immersion in the articles linked below.

What's passive immersion

What's a good active vs passive immersion ratio

responses:
Passive immersion (also sometimes called Semi-active immersion) is any immersion you do when you arent 100% focused on immersion. So this would be immersion when doing laundry, working out, cooking, driving, brushing your teeth. Whatever. The article below goes over passive immersion. But there are two things I want to clarify.

**How much passive immersion should I do?**
You want to do as much passive immersion as you can without sacrificing more important things, such as mental/physical health, safety, relationships, your job, etc. That being said, you NEVER want to sacrifice active immersion for passive. Passive immersion is only something you do when you are unable to do active immersion. 

**Passive immersion is misleading**
Passive immersion is a word created to let people know they can always find ways to fit more exposure to the language in, even if they can't fully focus. But in reality, focus is not binary; it's not on or off, black or white. It's a gradient. Sometimes during active immersion, you will lose focus and drift into passive. Other times during passive, you will focus in and get some active. The main thing is, you want to get as much exposure with as much focus as humanly and safely possible in the moment.

patterns: Is passive immersion effective

Is passive listening important
responses: The short answer is yes. The more nuanced answer is, usually. When learning a language,  you want as much exposure to that language as humanly possible without negatively affecting more important things (like health, job, relationships etc). The higher quality your immersion, the more benefit. But anything is better than nothing. If you just have Japanese on in the background and paying zero focused attention to it at all, then no, it's not likely to give much benefit. But who knows, it might provide some minor benefit. But, maybe for 2 hours you don't pay attention to it, then you have 30 seconds where you do focus on it because there is a lull in whatever you are doing. Well, for those 30 seconds, you basically get **active immersion** or at least semi-active immersion. Every little bit adds up over time. It's just up to you to decide if it's worth the effort and sacrifice. I think the related question will provide some more useful information potentially.

patterns: How much intensive immersion should I do
what ratio of intensive to free flow should I do
responses:
Intensive immersion is recommended to be a supplement to free flow immersion. While it is a powerful tool, you want to be careful about interfering with the natural acquisition process. Because of this, we recommend 30 minutes of intensive immersion a day. If you feel you want to do more, then go ahead and do more. Just be careful you aren't using intensive immersion as a crutch because you can't accept ambiguity. Even with intensive immersion, accepting ambiguity is an important element of the process.

Another thing to keep in mind, if you have much more passive immersion time than you do active immersion, you may want to do a little bit more intensive immersion during your active immersion and then use your passive immersion as the majority of your free flow exposure. But even if this is the case, make sure you are getting a healthy amount of free flow immersion during your active immersion time as well.

Be extra careful to also not burn out doing too much intensive immersion.

The answer is different for each stage of the process, so make sure you follow the Refold website's recommended advice. With that being said, here is a short answer. What you chose to read, subtitles, manga, light novels, etc, is up to you. But check related quesitons.

In stage 1, you want to focus primarily on listening. This way, you train your ear to hear the sounds of the language before associating them to the writing system too much. Watching content with Japanese subtitles isn't exclusively considered reading; it is more a hybrid activity providing clues to what you hear. 

In phase 2, if you chose, you can start reading more. Once you decide to start adding more reading, you want to try and keep your reading and listening comprehension levels somewhat even. So if one gets out of sync, spend more time with that activity to keep them about even.

It's also important to keep in mind that interests and goals come into play also. Some care more about reading than listening/speaking and vice versa. So spend time with the activity you care about, just know that too much in one direction, or the other will lead to less skill in the other. Find the balance that works for you. For most people, the recommended ratios and method that Refold lays out should work just fine. What you read and when is up to you. See related qeustions

reading and listening ratio

Reading and listening balance
responses:
Once you start reading, which is generally in stage 2, we recommend a 70/30 balance or a 50/50 balance. If one aspect is stronger than the other (for example, if your reading is stronger than your listening), listen 70 and read 30 percent. If the two are somewhat equal in strength, then immerse in a 50/50 ratio.

This assumes that you want to keep listening and reading balanced, which we recommend. Some, however, want to be more listening dominants and care about reading less. In contrast, others want to be more reading dominants and don't care as much about listening. So in that case, you will have to find what balance works for you and your goals.

patterns: What is the most important aspect of immersion
whats the most essential part of immersion
What are the most important parts of immersion
what are the most crutial elements of immersion
responses:
Anybody doing Refold for more than a few months knows that immersion is the most critical element of the process. But what are the most essential aspects of the immersion itself? Here are a couple.

**Focus**
Making sure you are focused on your immersion fully during active immersion is essential. Don't be checking emails, don't be scrolling social media. Engage in and focused on your content to signal to your brain that this is important. It's impossible to stay 100% focused for hours at a time, but the goal should be to be as focused as humanly possible at all times. Even if all you can muster is glazed eyes after work. Anything is better than nothing, but focus is better than anything.

**Give your brain things to figure out - Be curious**
 You want to watch your content with the intent to understand. The content you consume should be interesting to you. You should WANT desperately to understand it. This will make you hunt down for clues of what things mean. Your brain will take these curiosities and continue trying to figure them out in your subconscious even when you aren't immersing. So don't just go into immersion with the intent to check off your immersion boxes for the day. Remind yourself that this is something you want to understand and enjoy, and then try your best to do it. Even if you fail for a long time.

patterns: is reading important
why is reading important
should I be reading
how important is reading
responses: Reading seems to be where the most significant gains in pure language ability are formed. However, too much reading and not enough listening is thought to have negative ramifications on pronunciation, pitch accent instincts, as well as a natural use of spoken vocabulary over written vocabulary. However, it does seem to speed up the process quite a bit. This is why Refold recommends balancing the two the way we do. Focusing on listening only during stage 1 to build a solid foundation and then working into a more balanced approach in stage 2 so you get the best of both worlds. However, depending on your goals, you can balance this however you want. Some may want to go more listening heavy, while others may enjoy going more reading heavy. This will be influenced both by your goals and what type of immersion you enjoy most.

patterns: Is reading easier then listening

is it normal for my reading to be better than my listening
responses: I would say yes. For most people, reading is more manageable than listening. The visual cues that reading gives help support comprehension so much that it takes most people much longer to develop solid listening skills than reading skills. However, while you do have to do a significant amount of listening, to a certain extent, reading will improve your listening as well as it will increase how comfortable you are with sentence structures and vocabulary.

patterns: why should I not read first
Why does refold recomend only listening at first
why recomend only listening in stage 1
why does Refold not have you read early on
why don't we read early
why don't we read in stage 1
responses:
Refold recommends focusing on listening first and training your ear to hear the sounds of the language before worrying about reading. There are many reasons for this. I'll touch on them quickly.

1. Gives you time to get a kanji foundation. Decks like the Refold JP1K develop a kanji foundation through exposure to kanji in vocabulary but without testing your ability to read the kanji. This gets you familiar with the building blocks of kanji slowly over time. This gives you time to build that foundation before worrying about putting it to use.

2. Train your ear. Your brain likely can't hear all the sounds of the language when you first start. It takes tons of exposure to the language to even hear it properly, so while you gain a vocab and grammar foundation, it's best to work on building your ability to hear the language since you won't be able to understand what you are consuming anyway. Once you have even a 50 vocab foundation, you will start putting those listening skills to great use.

3. There is some evidence that reading too early can create a link in your mind between the sounds of the language and the writing system. This can cause a slightly lagged listening comprehension experience later on because your brain is always relating it to the writing system rather than just processing the sound. Some believe this "link" can't be undone. But even if it can, it takes a lot of time, so we feel to help avoid this, it's best to get a solid listening foundation before reading.

responses: One isn't better than the other. They both serve a purpose. I will say that intensive immersion should be used sparingly. You definitely want to do at least 5 times more free flow immersion than intensive. Intensive immersion helps you process the language at whatever speed you need to pick out new vocabulary and new concepts. However, it can also make you overthink the language and interfere with the subconscious natural language acquisition process. So while it's important to use intensive immersion to bring attention to new concepts, you want to also make sure you are getting a lot of free flow immersion so you are solidifying the stuff you know into automatic, fully acquired, pure language skill.

Try and figure it out like a detective. Pretend that if you can summarize whatever scene properly to a friend, you win a million dollars. Hunt down meaning. NEED and desire to understand the story in front of you. It's this type of focus where language acquisition thrives.

Is immersion useful

is immersion required
responses:
Immersion is the most essential part of the process. It is through immersion that our subconscious begins to form its instinctual understanding of the language. Seeing vocabulary and concepts repeatedly in new, novel contexts signals to our mind that it is important and should be remembered not just in the context of the SRS but all the time.

You will find that if you don't immerse, you will get vocabulary correct every time in Anki, but then when it comes time to use it, or you see it in a new context, you can't recall it. The brain is VERY context-dependent, so you NEED to give it exposure to all these things you are learning in hundreds and hundreds of contexts. This is just one of the many many reasons why immersion is so important.

Don't fool yourself into thinking study or Anki is where the gains are made. They are a supplement. The true magic is in immersion. Aacquisition of the language.

patterns: Should I freeflow or intensive while reading
Should I use intensive or passive for reading
responses: Both. Intensive and free-flow immersion can both be done with Reading or Listening. Many feel intensive immersion works best with reading, but members do it with listening as well. I recommend finding a balance, do a little intensive with both reading and listening, and see which you like best. Free-flow should be the vast majority of your immersion, though.

patterns: How to get back into immersing
how do I get back into immersing after a long break
responses: Just do it. Don't be afraid to start small and work your way back up slowly to a more respectable immersion schedule. Even if you immerse 5 min a day and gradually increase that daily goal over time, as long as you work towards that recommended 2+ hour minimum, it is progress.
